column2: Nobody special, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Tried using it a couple times in the past 5 yrs either for depression or smoking cessation (and sometimes both).  Was on 300mgs XR each time & I managed to stay on it for at least a month (often 2-3) every time, but this stuff just turns me into a lazy sloth no matter what!.  Some people seem to be under the impression that its a stimulant but no way (I am actually on add meds so I know the difference): just wait until you've been on it for a full month, then you'll see! You'll see that it's like any other antidepressant in that it turns you into an apathetic zombie only you'll be way less choosy and you'll eat anything in sight.  I also found that this stuff DID NOT help my ADD in ANY way, but then again I actually have add for reals and am not just self-diagnosing myself.  I believe this could help calm hyperactivity though, so maybe it's good ADHD.

column2: JPear70, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I live in the Pacific Northwest and wanted something to help with long winter depression and day to day anxieties and issues. I have taken SSRI's and didn't like the sexual side effects so I asked my dr about taking Wellbutrin. I was told to take one 150mg for 3 days and then take two thereafter (300mg). On day one slight annoying headache, no appetite. Day two in the evening I got agitated, shaky, couldn't focus or able to think about what words to put together, heart racing, still didn't want to eat. My husband said it was like I was on speed. In the middle of the night woke up drenched in sweat. Next morning eyes and head hurt. Hard to concentrate, foggy head and still unable to think and put words together. Decided to quit taking. Today I was looking at the bottle and it says these are 300mg tabs. If I took these as my dr told me AND as it says on the bottle I would have been taking 600mg by day four!!! I need to find out who messed this one up, dr or pharmacy. Good lesson to really read those pill bottles closely! Thank goodness I stopped them...who knows if I would have even seen that before I got to day four. I won't even pursue a lesser dosage. Too scared of it all now. If I really wanted to take meth I can get that anywhere without a  prescription! But keep in mind everyone handles these meds differently. Apparently this one is not for me.

column2: Texan9831221, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have SAD(Seasonal Affective Disorder)and I have taken both the 300 & 150 mg Wellbutrin XL during the winter months for 8 years. It didn't help me to quit smoking, I did lose a few pounds in the beginning though.  After taking for a week or so I start having trouble sleeping at night. I'm wide awake after 4 hours of sleep but it only lasts for a couple of weeks and then I sleep fine.  They both make me a little scatter brained but especially the 300mg.  It's hard to concentrate.  But as far as the depression goes its great.  The GENERIC did not work AT ALL!  I've had many rounds with my insurance getting them to pay for the name brand but the generic simply did nothing for me.  My doctor had to call them and write on the prescription "Name brand medically necessary".  Increase thirst is the only side affect.  It's easy to wean yourself off of these. I don't recommend quitting cold turkey.  Hope this helps someone.

column2: Survivor, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: At my psychiatrist request I tried Paxil then Zoloft, what a disaster that was. Horrible felt worse. She then put me on Wellbutrin, thank god. This was my magic pill. After my moms passing and other bad circumstances I realized I was seriously  depressed. I tolerated the pill very well. In no time I felt wonderful better than I ever felt. My sex life was great too, and since this natural type of energy helps boost the kind of neurotransmitter needed for optimal happiness, I was on cloud nine. I was able to go back to college and concentrate on things that were important rather than to dwell and fuel bad thoughts that kill me rather than aid me. I love this antidepressant, however; word of caution it might not be for everybody and all types of mental disorders. Use with caution and ward off any bad thoughts while your brain gets used to it.  Cognitive therapy and weekly psychotherapy helps a lot as well.

column2: intricate_eyes, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I took 150mg of the generic bupropion HCL XL, once per day in the morning. First thing I noticed on the second day of taking it was that I was unusually short of breath, and my heart started being quickly randomly throughout the day. On the fifth day I woke up with a sore left arm, and the pain spread to the left side of my chest. Developed chest pressure and that continued on for the full 8 days that I took the medication and ended when I went off the medicine. My anxiety also seemed to have increased; I could never calm down and my body always felt heavy. However, the only somewhat positive thing I can mention is that I felt that this medicine kind of woke me up a bit; before I was pretty numb, but I started feeling again. The side effects were enough to make me go off of it within 8 days. I hope to try the name brand Wellbutrin to see if there is an improvement.

column2: LizinVegas, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: This drug is doing a great job for me. I have been on it for 12 years. I originally took 150mg once a day; moved up to twice a day but switched to 300mg slow release so I wouldn't forget to take one of the doses. I tried so many different drugs over the past 20 years that I've lost count and the side affects were often horrific. Once my psychologist recommended Wellbutrin and my psychiatrist concurred I have never switched and it is the only anti-depressant I take. I also dropped 20 lbs of the 30 the other drugs had caused me to gain. It has helped with ADD, SAD and the all encompassing symptoms of depression. There have been a few times during the years when I was unable to take it for several days in a row and you could tell but just one dose and I was back up feeling great. I'm sorry it doesn't work for everyone; it has so few uncomfortable side affects when compared to some of the newer drugs. But for those who have found relief I can tell you that after all these years I still have found relief. (My husband calls them my happy pills!)

column9: I am A physical therapist and I was in cronic neck and upper bacj pain.  It gave me horrible anxiety, palpatations and made me very edgy.  It also prevented my from falling asleep which is obviously a problem within itself.  I knew my pain was not from my job, posture, or poor ergonomics. column2: Olythia, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Started these about 2 years ago after being  desperate because none of those that act on serotonin had worked for me. Best thing I ever did! I researched it on-line and found the ratio of people praising it to hating it was much more favourable than most other anti-depressants. Problem: I'm in the UK and it is only licensed for giving up smoking. So I have to order it from Europe or USA. I started by taking just a quarter of one 150mg tab and working up to the full dose by day 7. (different for everyone of course)Doing it this way made it much easier on the side-effects which for me were itchy rash on my hand and foot and difficulty getting to sleep maybe a bit of nausea but I found if I  ate some food with them it helped -even though my research said it shouldn't affect. I have read that taking a quarter of a tablet and building up gradually to lessen side-effects doesn't work. It really does for me. Bupropion has made me feel completely "normal" I didn't feel like I was on medication at all, until recently. After about a year and half I found I got occasional head pains. Not a headache as such. If I lay down on my front suddenly to watch television or something like that i would get a sharp pressure-like pain. I would keep still or slowly sit up and it would pass. after a few months I gradually started to get a slight hang-over feeling for a few hours most days. without any changes to my diet etc. I don't normally get headaches. My delivery was very delayed recently and I literally ran out. I was very worried what would happen with suddenly stopping (i could not get any from the doctor of course) Nothing happened so I stayed off them for two months. I can now very slightly feel anxiety on waking up that I used to get but only slightly so I decided to start again rather than wait until it gets bad. Today is the first day and I have a bit of that slight tightness in the head feeling. Anyone else had similar?

column2: KLouCB, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I do not recommend anyone take this medication Wellbutrin.  It caused my thoughts and behavior to be out of control.  I took it because my former MD said, "if you have chronic pain you also have depression". I have never been depressed in my life yet placed on Prozac and changed to Wellbutrin. This medication made me end up in a mental health ward where doctors automatically place a person on anti-psych drugs. Anti-psych medications are scary and should never be given to patients automatically.  Wellbutrin made my thoughts and actions so crazy and doctors since have told me that this is a common side affect.  Scary thought! Due to the fact I was discharged on these crazy drugs to take at home I continued to have scary thoughts and odd behavior.  This has been a nightmare that I would not wish on my worse enemy. Ive been in and out of psych wards for four years due to drugs that are on the market and we are told we must take the medicine a doctor orders. The ER doctor sees my medical records of a former  mental illness and then send me back to be committed to a mental ward with several E.R.visits. It was a revolving door as I would be once again on medicine that alters ones thoughts and behavior. I am lucky as my doctor got me off of Wellbutrin and every time I have been forced into a mental health ward by an emergency room doctor, my doctor weans me off of these terrible drugs and I am back to my old self.  I never had a history of mental illness until I started taking Wellbutrin and then being forced to take anti-psych medications will make your brain think things you wouldn't believe and behave in an out-of-control manner.

column2: hopeful65, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: This medication has been a life saving treatment for me.  I have been on multiple drugs for my depression over the last several years and in and out of the hospital several times also.  I was put on the Welbutrin after my last hospitalization for attempting to take my own life earlier this year(2011).  I am currently on the maximum dose and I also take Lamictal(100mg)and Remeron(30 mg) to help with sleep.  I was like a zombie with the 5 meds I was on before my suicide attempt now I feel so much better.  For the first time in 6 yrs I have my energy back, I'm not falling asleep during the day,I am hopeful instead of hopeless and I am back working after an extended medicalleave.  I do see a therapist in addition to the medication currently and attribute the success of my recovery to the combination of the new medicine, therapy and the intensive care I received in my week and a half stay at a psychiatric hospital 6 months ago but I believe the medication change to Welbutrin has made a huge difference.  I hope my experience is helpful to someone out there who is suffering from this medical illness that can be difficult to treat.

column9: Have been on this med for about 5 years on and off for depression and lack on sexual desire due to Lexapro. Well, speaking to my psychiatrist who specializes in meds and heads the state board where I live, Wellbutrin was actually considered being used as a drug for lacking sexual desire when they did their initial studies. This was due to the results of the initial tests showing increased sexual desire of women and actual orgasm without stimulation. It was being studied at this time to see positive effects for depression. It helped me the first time I took it although I felt like a nympho. Back on it again 3 years ago to help libido but doing nothing but causing constipation...no sexual desire at all. Actually wish I was experiencing my initial use "urges" that caused me to stop it, was having "almost orgasms" at work and couldn't concentrate.

column2: AABurnett, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I was diagnosed with an anxiety disorder almost 20 yrs ago. At first it was just anxiety, but as the years have gone by I developed severe depression on top of it. I've tried just about every kind of "depression" medication on the planet, and Wellbutrin (the generic, Buproprion) has been the one that's helped me the most. The depression has gotten 90% better during the time I've been taking it. Still have anxiety issues (but I've got Xanax for that...LOL)...but I'd rather be anxious than depressed any day.I have to take this medication in the morning, otherwise it's hard to get to sleep at night. And I'm carrying around several extra pounds, but I think that all depression meds make you gain weight. After reading some of these reviews, it's obvious that everyone reacts differently to this medication as far as "side effects" are concerned. For the first week after I started taking it, side effects were a little rough...my hands shook really bad at times, I had a hard time sleeping, and I was a little nauseated. After my body adjusted to it (and it takes about a week) the symptoms subsided & everything was fine.On the plus side ~ after I'd been taking Wellbutrin for about 6 months, I quit smoking. One of the nice little side effects of this medication. ; )If you have depression and haven't tried Wellbutrin yet, give it a try. I was pleasantly surprised.

The first couple of weeks were actually OK, but once it built up in my system I experienced severe headaches, dizziness, ear ringing, nausea, night sweats, insomnia, and nightmares. The drug also caused my system to violently reject ANY other central nervous system drug I put in my body. Couldn't have a drink, a cup of coffee, or even take an ibuprofen without feeling just awful. So I stopped. That was 2 years ago. Not the end of the story, however. column2: Madelyn, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had a serious problem with the generic wellbutrin- after a month of increasingly uncomfortable symptoms, I realized they had started with the generic. I could not get a good breath in- it was tight and no matter how hard I tried, it would take 5 or 6 deep breaths/yawns before I got one breath, then the process would start over. I had chest pain/tightness and an incredibly fast heartbeat. I exercise regularly and am only 24, so this was unusual. I ended up in the ER because my chest hurt so bad I worried I was damaging my heart. They couldn't find anything and wouldn't believe my generic accusation, until a social worker called a psychiatrist who confirmed my symptoms as a common side effect from this generic. I took Wellbutrin for anxiety and depression 8 years ago, and I was fine. I know my body has changed, but I believe this generic may be dangerous for some. With coupons, my co-pay will be $230... so now I will be either fighting or beginning again the struggle to find an adequate medication.

column2: Guinea pig, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: As a professional Guinea pig, Wellbutrin was but one of the anti-depressive drugs prescribed to me.  My doctor thought perhaps it would help with my obsessive/compulsive behavior.  It did not do anything for that.  I guess it helped with depression somewhat.  The problem arose when I noticed any time I'd lie down, whatever thought was in my head would vaporize.  Trying to remember exactly what I'd been thinking would not get it back to save my soul.  Sometimes, I would write down my thoughts, then lie down just to see if they'd go poof (they would)---at least I could read about what was on my mind just minutes before.  However, even reading the subject would not return the thoughts themselves.  When I brought this up to my doctor, he said, "Uh-oh."  Apparently, I was suffering seizures on Wellbutrin, which caused my mind to reset to 0.  I was immediately taken off this drug and another was tried--and another--whichever had the best sales pitch.  I ultimately did find an extended-release antidepressant that works perfectly for my particular needs.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I just started taking this drug today, and after reading the reviews I am concerned about the generic version I was given (Bupropion XL, I think). According to one article, it's the patented membrane that allows for extended release that seems to be the problem. Apparently some generics don't use the same XR method, which can lead to a huge release of the active ingredient followed by little to no release. Wellbutrin has a membrane-like wall that allows a constant release, but many generics use pills that just dissolve slowly. Other bodily functions can speed up or slow down the release (i.e., amount of food in stomach). Just thought this was interesting so I'm passing it along and will also ask my doctor about it.  http://www.prevention.com/health/health/healthy-l iving/find-out-how-to-use-generic-drugs-safely/ar ticle/ca929d93636d6110VgnVCM10000013281eac____

In 09 my doctor prescribed me Prozac 20 mg and i didn't like the though of being on medicine so i didn't take it reguarly  which is bad. It made my tired and it just did not work. My doctor was a prozac pusher lol. To make a long story short in October 2010 i wanted another advise and saw another doctor and he put me on WELLBUTRIN XL 150 Mg later uped me to 300mg. I though wow thats so much medicine compared to 20mg but he explained to me how it works differently and it has different mg and 150 isn't so much. 4 Months later now Feb 2011 i feel great and have lost 45 lbs in 3 months. column2: medwisegirl, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Wellbutrin has been great for me. All I wanted to do before taking this was sleep, and when I was up I was grouchy and irritated. I actually like getting up in the morning and enjoy my day. Everyone around me is much happier as well. I tried Cymbalta first and it didn't fit my specific needs, and in fact worsened my depression. There are different medicines for different types of depression. Wellbutrin works on the neurotransmitter dopamine. Dopamine is for motivation and acivating the reward center in the brain. I wouldn't discourage or encourage the use of this drug. It's your doctors job, depending on your depression symptoms, to match you with the best medicine for you. You need not listen to people that say not to try it, everyone is different. This medicine may or may not work for you. Treating depression is not an exact science, due to our lack of knowledge about the brain. Finding the right depression medicine will take trial and error, which can be very frustrating. Stick with it and you will find a medicine that works for you.

column2: MagDel, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: 300mg dosage Wellbutrin XLGeneral Dysthymia & Sleeping ProblemsPros:The increased energy levels and motivation have really helped.  The initial euphoric/hyper feelings dissipate quickly but are still enjoyable for the first few days.  Bad thoughts and anxiety tend to pass much more quickly.  Bad moods and sadness are not nearly as "low" as they were before.  It makes it much more easy to combat problems instead of dwelling on them.  Improved sleep seems to be a result of the other effects.Cons:Constipation is sometimes a problem, but this can be dealt with through proper diet.I also get more thirsty throughout the day.Neutral:Really reduces hunger pangs and overall appetite.  This has been very helpful for losing the weight put on while depressed.  It may not be good for those who are already lean.

column2: catlover959, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I has a life threatining illness last yr. and was hospitalized several times. One stay was 28 days. I'm a heavy smoker and was given patches in the hosp. Not taking wellbutrin but going to start next week. My point is this: I was not just irritable, I was furious, until they got my patch on and all that went away. Maybe what you are calling side effects from the meds are actually withdrawl from the nicotine. I was astounded that I could feel such rage. But as I said, after patch got in to my system all the went away. I see there are two different kinds of wellb. one is ss and one is xl. Could someone tell me the difference. Also I was treated with many drugs, one being cumadin, the blood thinner, for a blood clot that in my leg that had went to my lung six times. I began to notice that when the generic was used, actuallly with all the drugs I had to take, I noticced that the generic drugs were a joke. My doc told me that drug co. have a 10% leway on what they put in meds. That is awful. Generics DO NOT work for me. and i can't afford the name brand. Has anyone else noticed this? and is there any way we can make a complaint to some organization.I did not mean to mislead about being on the medication, but I will be on it this time next week.

column2: Pat,  Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Caregiver)

column2: DontHaveOne, 13-18 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: My 16 yr old son has been having problems in school for 2 yrs:Poor grades due to not doing homework, also seemed have low self esteem and some mild depression (caused by above?). Hanging out with a "bad" crowd and some drug abuse. He's been in behavioral therapy for 2 years - I finally said, ok, nothing I am doing is working (therapy, life coach skills, summer school).  I was looking into wilderness camp for him too. But, I did not want to put my son on drugs for poor grades.  I did not want him on amphetamine drugs - adamantly. He has been on Wellbutrin 150mg 1x/day for a month.  The change was almost immediate. He wanted to cut his hair shorter - which gave him a real boost when the kids (girls) noticed.  He has gone from a F/D/C student to an A student (it's only the 3rd week of school - so we'll see).  Teachers he has (again) have noticed the change and love it.  He is my son again.   He still has the dumb friends, he still  is smoking uknowwhat I am sure - but it does not seem to be his all emcompassing thought.  He wants to go to the Jr Dance, he is exercising and taking pride in his appearance, he is talking to other kids too at school and noticing the difference in kids.   I am thankful I tried this medicine.  Even though the change is seems drastic - it feels "normal" to him, not like he is BAM someone new - just an improved version of him.  My only thought is that after only being on this for one month his Doctor wanted to increase him from 150 to 300mg - I don't understand that - why kick it up (soo much after only a month) when it's fine?  So, I said we'll try the 200mg - which is not timed release - lasts 8 hrs and if my son does not like it - we will go back to 150mg time release.  I guess the 300mg is timed release - but why drink Mountain Dew when a glass of water is really all you need?

column2: daienu, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: After 4 years of fatigue, a complete physical breakdown, and a range of mysterious illnesses I was misdiagnosed with depression and an eating disorder. I was prescribed first Zoloft, then to fight the fatigue caused by it, Wellbutrin XL. As soon as I started taking WB I began to feel more energized, awake at 5.30 am, just like another reviewer, more alive. This was during the winter months. At this time I was also taking a small amount of Zoloft, that was upped a little while later to 200 mg's, at which point I began to feel worse. Than my wellbutrin was upped to 300 mg's,and I began to feel better again. I then ran our of Zoloft completely, and my medication provider failed to reorder it for me, so I remained without it for nearly five weeks. They were wonderful weeks. While the first few days I felt dizzy, I did not feel more emotional or irrational in any way. my doctor, however, insisted I go back on it when it arrived. Sadly. Getting back on that was a rough road. Only two years later, when I was diagnosed with lupus, could I stop. Wellbutrin has been amazing. Yes, it comes with some photosensitive side effects, not so fun for lupus patients, but the good outweighs the bad. Long term, i agree, the effects seem to fade a little. I don't like being without it. It helps another friend with Irritable bowel syndrome, it helped me lose a few pounds. Neither the generic, nor the 150 mg format is a good substitute for the extended release (XL). It has been great and I highly recommend it if you must be on antidepressants.

column2: abirata, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Wellbutrin had side effects at the beginning - the worst of which were insomnia and constipation. The insomnia abated after about 3 weeks of treatment and I take a fiber supplement to deal with the constipation. It also abates with time but never completely goes away. Another side effect at firt was a general "hyper" feeling but that also wore off after a few weeks. Unlike the SSRIs, Wellbutrin does not make me feel "drugged - I feel emotions, good and bad - but the difference I notice while taking the drug is that I tend not to brood or obsess over negative events or ideas, it is easier to let them pass. I think it has also made me more able to open up to talking about my situation because I dont think I have to reign in my bad emotions so tightly as I dont fear them getting out of control. It is easier to work through them, and talk about them. Wellbutrin by itself is a great help, but by far the most effective treatment for me has been talk therapy. Depression runs in the family. I did not start seeking treatment until age 27 when it became overwhelming  and was affecting my work and relationships. The first course of treatment my physician prescribed were SSRIs (Paxil, Prozac and Zoloft), but I could not tolerate the side effects nausea and drowsiness, but the worst, that although my depression was dampened, so were all my emotions. These side effects never abated. I became even more distant from people I loved and could not function effectively at work because it was difficult to concentrate. I had great doubts about all of the anti-depressants after those experiences, and am skeptical of drug claims and the pharmaceutical industry in general but have to admit that Wellbutrin has been very effective. I know that SSRIs are very effective for many  people - I just wanted to share that portion of my experience because I believed that because they did not work for me, nothing would. I am glad to be proven wrong.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have been taking Welbutrin 150mg for 11 days now. I really like the fact that I don't feel like I need to sleep all the time which I did when I was on Celexa. I also like the way it helps boost my mood and has definitely helped with my sex drive that had been non-existent with Celexa. However, I am waiting for some of the side effects to wear off. My doctor said to give it a few more weeks before I decide if I like it or not. From day two I have been dizzy. It is better now than it was, but still feeling it. I also have been very nauseas and I have had a mild headache, kinda feels like a sinus headache. I also have had hot flashes and night sweats and my ADHD is actually worse. I find that odd since this drug can also be taken for ADHD. If the side effects fade I am all for this medicine, but if they don't there is no way I can keep taking it. I have also had some trouble sleeping, but as long as I take at least half of my dose of Neuratin and Buspar a few hours before bed I am fine. If I forget to take it early I can't take it at all because I need 12 hours before getting up to get those two out of my system or I can't find it hard to wake up on time. I'm gonna give it one more week and if the side effects don't fade it is back to the doc for our next trial and error run.

column2: Pammie, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: The medication was effective however the side effects is great Not able to sleep, not able to eat, then when the appetite returns hve a chaving to eat 24*7 unusual dreams that seem to be real

column2: helpless, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Initially it gave me more energy and I did not feel the need to sleep all of the time.After taking it for three years I have started to feel anxious and panicy after taking it in the morning. I went to a new doctor yesterday and he suggested cutting down on the dosage.  Hopefully this will help.  I am experiencing a new episode of depression.

column2: JustSayNO, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I use to take Wellbutrin many years ago for depression. This was before they came out with the SR and XL. You had to take it using a starter kit that had a certain dosage for each day. Side effects were minimal for me except for severe upset stomach for the initial 2 to 3 weeks. It eventually subsided. My doctor said that side effect is rare. Well NOT 4 me. My doctor wrote me a prescription for XL 300 the other day to help me stop smoking. Im assuming the extended release formula replaces the need for the gradual starter kit. I sure hope so otherwise taking 300mg from the get go may be intolerable for my digestive system. It worked pretty well for my depression but what I remember most was the effect it had on reducing my smoking. Cigs tasted like sucking on molded burnt logs. I quit the medication because at that time I really wanted to enjoy my cigarettes again. Idiot I know. Not this time though. Those old molded burnt logs are going to be thrown out never to return. I suggest this medicine for smoking cessation over that new Cymbalta stuff. It has the same indications at about a tenth of the price. Cimbalta is just ripping people off. I really doubt it affects the brain much differently than does Wellbutrin. Especially when only taken for a short period. Wellbutrin is indicated for smoking cessation. If it was harmful to people who are not depressed I doubt that this purpose would be listed as one of the uses. If I could afford the Cimbalta I'd try it instead just to see how it compares for me versus Wellbutrin in altering the taste of cigarettes. My guess is Cymbalta does not work as well as Wellbutrin for this purpose. It was marketed differently probably due to the stigma some have for taking anti-depressants. It will interesting to see what the effects,if any,while taking when not depressed. It may have the effects of ecstacy...lol doubtful but it would make for quite an experience. Probably would not curb my craving for a cigarette. Will post results later

column2: JenS., 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Wellbutrin was a life saver for me. I was diagnosed with Major Depression 5 years ago and initially was prescribed Celexa. I felt a little better but still had no concentration or energy. My psychiatrist added Wellbutrin XL and it turned out to be the answer I needed. I would not have survived my depression without the addition of Wellbutrin to my celexa (300mg Wellbutrin and 40 mg Celexa). I know some people have shared negative side effects of this drug but you will not know unless you try it. It worked well for me but it is not for everyone. If you have depression please do not give up on finding the right medication for you. It just takes some time. I have been on meds and in individual therapy and it has been successful  in treating my depression. I am now to the point where I am titrating my Wellbutrin so that I can be med free and start a family. Thank you Wellbutrin for giving me my life back!

column2: 13-18 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: i took wellbutrin for two years. not only did it make my dpression MUCH worse, but it made me numb. like my skin was always numb. i couldnt feel phisical pain. it was INSANE. also it upset my stomach to the point that i couldnt eat or drink ANYTHING unless i skipped my meds.this is probably the single WORST drug to ever be invented. i urge you before trying this drug to examine every other possible option with your doctor. everyone i have ever met who has taken this has had severe problems with it.

column2: Disappointed, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)

I see the doc tomorrow and wil try something else. I do want to day I had the insomnia for about a week, the a rash for about 3 days, but th eside effects have pretty much disappeared, so if that is a concern for you, try to tough it out. If the med works, hang on until you get through the side effects.

I had horrible side effects including worsening depression, extreme sadness, constant crying, etc...it was a very bad time. as soon as i made the switch, it was like night and day. if bupropion doesn't work for you, don't write off wellbutrin. discuss taking the brand-name only with your doctor and see if it helps. column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I started taking Wellbutrin to help ease my seasonal depression & my DR said it would also help with the symptoms of my ADHD.  I took this drug when I was 20 turning 21, I quit taking the drug b/c I had bad side-effects (I figured out the only time I had those side-effects was when I was drinking alcohol) recently I realized I had a serious alcohol-abuse problem, I joined the Fellowship of Alcoholics Anonymous and I have been sober for 5 months. When working with my Psychiatrist in an attempt to control my ADHD (he wanted to work in my Alcohol Abuse) I asked him if I could try Wellbutrin again.  I have only been taking it this go around, for less than a week, I take Wellbutrin in addition to Trazadone (for sleep) Lexapro (my opinion the BEST anti-depressant) Adderall (for ADHD), one of the 'benefits' I am receiving from Wellbutrin is the cessation my my nicotine cravings! The other 'benefits' I am experiencing: more 'real' energy (not too much) I am able to get through the day without PRAYING I can go to bed when I get home at 6pm, also I can THINK much more clearly, I have patience now (I didn't realize I wasn't very patient before), I have a reasonable appetite during the day (Adderall suppresses appetite) I am calm and I cry a lot less than before :)I hope this helped: Charlene age 25

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)

The last day I took the medication (3 days ago) I experienced a panic attack while at work, and have since experienced 2 more panic attacks, each with worsening symptoms. Today is the 2nd day without medication and I am still having the palpitations... column2: ThereIsASolution, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I was on SRI's for 13 years, and was exhausted all the time, barely functioning, even though the dark depression was gone. I slowly switched from Effexor to Wellbutrin, I take 400mg in the morning now, then added Xanax .25 at night for anxiety. The effect was startling - in a few days, I hate much more energy and motivation. I used to have to take naps at work at lunchtime because I felt like I was going to almost faint - at least 2-3 times a week. I have done that for 10 minutes once in 2 years. I was able to do 5 years of taxes that I was too tired to tackle before, and I can function much better in general now. Made a huge difference in my life, night and day. Wellbutrin affects dopamine levels much more than most of the SSRI's, I believe that's the reason. I am a recovering alcoholic (26 years sober), and drinking affects dopamine too, so I can see why Wellbutrin works for me.

column2: softtouch, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I think this is just great for me after about 4 weeks. Started at 150 for about 3 weeks and then went to 300 for over a week now. column9: i was on wellbutrin 100mg bc of mood swings for 1 month before my dr increased my dose to 150mg.  i read into all side effects listed on webmed like i do with all meds.  webmd states siezures as a rare sife effect with wellbutrin. i had been on 150mg for less than 1 month when i took my 9month old son to see my parents.  i had been there for about 15mins when i fell out and had a convolsive siezure. luckly i was not driving/alone/holding my child.  my dr did reseach and found out that in fact 1 out of every 1000 people have siezures while on wellbutrin.  i then spoke with coworkers & found additional people i knew that wellbutrin caused siezures with.  turns out siezures are not as rare of a side effect that they make it seem. again my dr found that every 1 in 1000 people wellbutrin causes siezures in.

column2: Christine, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: The Brand Wellbutrin XL 300 mg works very well for me, with Lamictal 200 mg and ongoing psychotherapy. It stabilizes my mood swings effectively. However, my insurance company decided to switch me to generic form of Wellbutrin. I assumed it was working for me until I hit bottom and was so out of control I didn't know what to do. I wasn't in therapy at the time. My GP was continuing the prescriptions and follow up with me after I moved away from my therapist. My GP recognized that I was in trouble during a routine exam and sent me immediately to a therapist she highly recommended. This therapist works closely with a psychiatrist that I am now seeing.  She recognized that the problem was the generic form of Wellbutrin (I wasn't taking Lamictal at that time).  I read several reviews by patients experiencing the same problem, with the same symptoms, which I found on the internet. I owe my life to these doctors for recognizing the problem and switching me back to Brand Wellbutrin XL.  My insurance company still won't cover the Brand but insists on the generic even though my doctors have explained the problem and insisted that I take the Brand name drug. I have to pay full price for Wellbutrin or suffer the dire consequences.  I have now ordered the drug from a reputable pharmacy in Canada at a lower price.

januarymom, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Typical story...busy mom of 2 fighting mild depression.  My "mild" depression includes a general feeling of lethargy, difficulty motivating myself to do simple things, feeling overwhelmed with the thought of completing simple tasks.  I was functioning in life but at a  lower level.  Anyway onto the med review:  MD prescribed 100 mg 1x a day and then told to work up to 200 mg 1x a day after a week.  First week at 100 mg....tons of headaches, crazy dehydration, wierd flighty feeling, nauseus, lack of appetite.  I convinced myself to stick with it at uped my dose.  Experienced 4 days of the worst headaches of my life.  I had to quit completely b/c I couldn't function.  Waited a week and began 100 mg once a day again and this time no headaches,  I am sticking with my low dose since it seems to give me the extra lift I need.  I don't feel medicated or foggy.  The biggest thing to disappear was the feeling of being overwhelmed.  I feel like a weight was lifted off my shoulders.  As for side effects now...I have a tendency to get dehydrated more quickly when on the meds so I have to really drink alot of water.  If I don't hydrate the headaches follow.  Initially my appetite completely disappeared.  Now it's less but not significantly.  This med does seem to reduce cravings in general.  I am not a drinker but had a couple drinks (despite my better judgement) on NY's Eve.  The next day or 2 I felt like the meds weren't working.....felt lethargic, just down.  Definately not worth the drinks of Champagne so I'll abstain 100% for now.  I am at a much lower dosage then is prescribed for most people but it works for me.   Main con i that I do notice that I can become agitated quicker.  I am usually the most laid back person, almost too laid back.  So for me it's not a big deal but I wouldn't recommend this med to anyone who has a tendency to anger easily or experiences anxiety.

column2: mlarrobinson, 75 or over Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I am not surprised to see other people having headaches with this drug. I took the 2 a day version for 5 months before not being able to stand the headaches anymore.  I also felt very jittery the first week or so.  I recently switched to the extended release medication and my headaches are gone!  My doctor said that maybe the large dose twice a day was like a fire that then burned out over & over.  I would definitely recommend the extended version of this drug.  In the past I had taken zoloft and I did feel great.  A little too great.  I gained 30 lbs over 6 months and had NO libido.  And I couldn't sleep at night to boot!  I did love how I felt, but I had to sleep and I didn't want to take a medication to sleep every night on top of the zoloft.  I like the welbutrin better for me because it only lessened my symptoms enough to be able to wrap my head around the issues in my life that were completely overwhelming me.  It didn't mask the problems as I felt the zoloft did.  Only helped me feel like I could compartmentalize them and start to deal with them.  Definitely make your doctor give you the extended release!

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Caregiver)
column9: My granddaughter, who is afflicted with Turner's Syndrom, was born with many broken cromazones, was put on Wellbutrin when she was about 10 years old to control her obsessive/compulsive hyperactive behavior. She began to withdraw from her normal behavior, and her school work regressed to about a 2-3rd grade level.  Her memory was affected dramatically.  We removed her from the Wellbutrin treatment after we heard similar stories about the effects.  She began a slow recovery and is functioning at a high level now.  Her ability to know left from right, tell time and several other skills that she had for several years were severely affected and she continues to struggle with some of these issues.

column2: rytawn, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have been on several medications in the past..celexa,lexepro etc. All of which caused me to feel blah and emotionless. They also caused weight gain and sexual disfunction. When I felt that things were getting bad again I asked my Dr if he could try me back on that. I immediately had more energy, better attentin span, weight loss and better sex. I am only taking half the dose prescribed, 150mg in the morning. I am now at a plateau, so I may begin taking my second dose of 150 mg early afternoon. The only side effects are slight hand tremors, some irritability and my heart races especially if I have a few drinks. Not enough side effects to give it up. Really, if the other drugs you are taking make you feel lifeless, ask your Dr to try this. When I went off this the first time I had way less withdrawl sickness than the others.

column2: CRZYGRL, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Over the past 15yrs I have tried Zoloft,Luvox & Prozac. Zoloft made me feel like a "zombie",Luvox and Prozac I pretty much plateaued on where they weren't effective anymore. When I first started taking Wellbutrin XL I felt great! My depression was at bay,I had energy,felt good myself,lost 60lbs. Now I have reached a plateau or something, and I feel horrible!I am extremely depressed,do not have any interest in anything I use to do,I have racing thoughts of challenging myself to do things that could harm me, I have no energy,I have gained back at least 40lbs. Im full of anxiety, which i am taking Xanax for. I can cry at any given moment for no reason. These are all side effects I have been feeling since BEFORE my dr started weaning me off. Its only been a month since I started to wean off and I really haven't felt much of an improvement yet. My dr said it may take several weeks before I start to feel any change.  I am so frustrated because I just want to feel normal. I feel that this is not a long term "drug" for some people. It is definetly not helping me anymore. column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Wellbutrin helped me get my life back. I have BP and had an episode of severe depression that lasted several months last year. Before that, my episodes were manic except for a depressive episode when I was sixteen. The mania is not as severe or as lengthy as it was in my late teens and early/middle twenties so Lamictal alone has been enough to keep me stable at this point. After 10 weeks on Wellbutrin I finally started to crawl out of the dark pit. My current regimine is 300 Lamical at night and 300 Wellbutrin XL in the morning. The Wellbutrin causes ringing in the ears. I don't notice it too much until I sit down at the end of the day to relax (I have two small children). I enjoy reading, but am distracted too much by the ringing to concentrate. I am tolerating it because Wellbutrin has worked so well for my depression. Also, I had been on a generic and my Pharmacy switched to another generic brand and it really messed me up. I was very anxious (I don't suffer normally), confused, dizzy and had a strong metallic taste. My doc said that she's had other similar complaints and recommended switching to the name brand. I did and since then have been back to as close to normal as I'll ever get LOL:) Also, to all those suffering from sleep problems and irritability, do you drink caffeine? I'm very sensitive to it and have been off of it for six years. On occassion I will "splurge" and have a sweet tea or Dr. Pepper at a resturant, but then I'm very jittery, irritable, hyper and VERY chatty. When I finally go to bed (2-3 am) I wake up often which impacts my mood and concentration the next day...vicious cycle, so I stay away from it.

column9: I suffer from irritability, lack of motivation, depression, and anxiety. I have been medicatited most of the last 10 years. But after 4 days of severe pain in the top of my head, I spoke to my Dr. who said a small percent of people will experience migrain from the Wb. The next morning I had an ice pack on my neck at six am. I took only the Celexa that day and realized around 11am my headache was almost gone! I still had tension and restlessness dry mouth. column2: odwassquad, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I question why some of you are taking Wellbutrin XL more than once a day?  It is an extended release version of the drug which should help eliminate the need to take it more than once a day.  Anyway, my best advice to anyone with depression and/or bi-polar disorder is to try any meds that are offered or are available.  It took a while to find the medications that worked for me.  Don't be worried about taking more than one drug either, if you need to.  I have been taking Wellbutrin XL for 3 1/2 YEARS.  I am taking 450 mg and have been for most of that time period.  I have had excellent results on this med, and have had no side effects at all, ever, nor have I had any significant weight gain.  This medicine has worked wonderful for ME.  I have bi-polar disorder; therefore I also take Lamictal 400 mg, and Seroquel 100 mg.  This is the "cocktail" of meds that have worked for me.  Medicine affects everyone differently.  Don't think that just because one person had serious side effects that you will also.  This medicine may be just what you need.  Sometimes you have to trust the doctor more than the reviewers.  The doctors know what the side effects may be.  They are in no way trying to hurt you!  They are trying to help you the only way they know how!  Good luck and God bless you!  There is hope, just don't give up!

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I had suffered from depression for years before I started taking Wellbutrin.  It has made a major positive difference in my life in the way I handle things; I am able to think much more clearly and rationally.  For the first few years I combined the medication with therapy.  I was taking 225 mg when I started and have had to increase it once to 300 mg/ day.  I currently take the Wellbutrin 300 XL.  Word of caution on the generic version of Wellbutrin 300 XL - I tried it when it was approved and found after a few months that I was becoming depressed again.  The generic did not work for me; the tablet may have the same amount of medication but the packing (what makes up the rest of the pill)is completely different than the brand name.  For me it seemed like instead of medication being steadily administered to my system throughout the day it hit all at once, thus the return of the depression.  I was hoping to be able to save some money with the generic but it is worth it to me to take the brand name.

column2: m3doc, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I am 54 yrs. old with clinical depression and have been on some kind of antidepressant for the last 25 yrs. with less than effective results. I've been taking Wellbutrin XL for over 4 years. I also was taking Cymbalta (didn't notice any help from that drug), but stopped due to the perceived ineffectiveness over 6 months ago with no negative effects. WB however seemed to help level out my depression. Instead of the very deep lows they became less severe over time until my mood was manageable. When I began taking WB I immediately noticed a decrease in appetite and lost several pounds right away. In time my appetite came back and have gained the weight back. It also helped with my cravings for habits I had stopped years ago, e.g., smoking, drinking, drugs, etc. If I wanted to stop smoking, drinking or drugs I would HIGHLY recommend WB as an adjunct therapy. I see why ZYBAN is prescribed for smoking cessation! I have tried weening back to 150mg from the 300mg dose I take daily before bed, but noticed mood changes within a week so I went back to 300mg, not wanting to fix it if it wasn't broken. It seems as though I may have to take something for the rest of my life as I have been a lifetime depression sufferer. The only side effect I suffer from is that I think it contributes to sexual dysfunction, but depression itself could be the main culprit. There is no free lunch with any medication. Your mileage may vary ;-).

column2: pesistent, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have been taking 150mg twice daily for 4mos and I feel so much better. I use to have crying spells at least four times a day.I have fibromyalgia syndrome and had surgery on my R shoulder for a tear in my rotator cuff and multi-directional stability.The surgery was successful but I still have chronic pain in it and limited range of motion.I take other prescibed pain pills,but it only takes the ease off of my daily chronic pain and symptoms.I whiched from effexor sr 75mg twice a day due to sexual delays?Im single but I one day plan to be married and dont want to hav any problems in that area of my life.I was in denial for yearrs.I have isolated myself for my friends and family with the belief that no one would honesty understand the pain and discomfort I experience daily and at my age?My crying spells are under control now since I have been taking Wellbutrin.I hav even visited my mother at least twice per wk and started talkn bac to at least one of my friends :-)I have alot more energy which is great because one of the symptoms of fibromyalgia is fatigue.And I have also regained at alot of lost memory and concentration.It has and will continue to be a very big part of my health management plan.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: This drug drastically improved my quality of life. Though I do not have a formal dx of MDD, I suffered from both depression and fatigue- not sure if it was fatigue as a symptom of depression, or that I was depressed because I was fatigued all the time post mono.  In any case, the Wellbutrin XL took care of both of them. In my experience having tried all three, the brand is the best, then the generic buproprion, and BY FAR THE WORST is the generic budeprion-HORRIBLE headaches.  Right now I have been taking 300mg of the generic buproprion for about a year because the brand got too expensive, even with insurance.  While on the brand drug, I lost about 10-15lbs but since have gained it back (not sure if it is related to swtiching from the brand to generic).  Side effects I experienced/still experience include a headache the first week on it, constipation the first week on it, and for the two years I have taken it I have had increased eye sensitivity to sunlight.  As a patient taking it and a registered nurse, I highly recommend this drug for patients experiencing depression with fatigue, especially if SSRI's increased your feeling of fatigue.

column2: ?, 65-74 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
Kathy O, 55-64 Female  (Patient)
column9: I have suffered from depression most of my life.  In my early 20s I started see a psychiatrist.  I received talk therapy as well as antidepressants throughout my life.  I have been off & on Prozac for the past 20 years.  For nearly two years, I have had trouble with sleeping too much (anywhere from 12 to 20 hours a night).  When I saw my regular doctor, she suggested increasing my Prozac to 40mg & said I should expect to stay on it for the rest of my life (I am 63).  With no improvement she added Effexor (75mg).  It didnt seem to improve the sleeping or depression.  Besides the excessive sleeping, I also felt like crying all the time; found no joy in life; had no energy; & no motivation to do anything (other than what was absolutely necessary ).  I went to a psychiatrist  and he decreased the Effexor  (37.5mg).  With still no improvement, he stopped the Effexor and started me on Wellbutrin (300mg).  Within about three weeks I felt like a normal person.  I would wake before the alarm would ring, had more energy and felt not so hopeless. I hadnt felt like this in a long time.  The change lasted about two months.   After he wrote the next prescription for Budeprion XL (300mg), which he said was cheaper.  I started to feel like I was going back to my old pattern of sleeping too much (not as bad as before but still too much) and not as much energy as with Wellbutrin..  I am sad to say I did not experience any weight loss with either the Wellbutrin or the generic.  While taking the generic, I had some adverse effects which include: dry mouth; tremors of the hands; increase in resting heart rate (85+ per minute); trouble keeping my balance and some hair loss.  When I see the psychiatrist in a month, I plan on having write a prescription for Wellbutrin, not the generic.  It is worth the extra money.

column2: WheelchairDude, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: 5/5 with this drug.  It has really helped me out in so many ways.  I have Muscular Dystrophty (FSH type).  Have been markidly depressed for about 6 years.  Nothing has worked, until I actually asked.. to try Wellbutrin.  Wellbutrin has changed my life.  It has definatly increased quality of life, over quanity of life.  Makes dealing with my everyday disease more at ease, with my physical weakness, and mental tiredness.  And what I like about it is, is that it doesn't make you feel "high" or "euphoria", well, to me anyways, but you just... feel good.  And that is quality of life to me.

column9: I am just changing over from prozac, and I like that this medication in weight friendly.

column2: ashleyamore, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I just began [this will be day 4] my treatment with wellbutrin. I tried to get an appointment with a psychiatrist only to be told that I couldn't be seen until the middle of august. [almost a full month from then]. I already had been suffering from severe daytime anxiety, but one night I awoke with what I would later find out was a nocturnal panic attack. This was very scary for me, as I thought it could've been sleep apnea, and my nighttime panic attacks were MUCH worse than my daytime ones, which is saying something. My heart would race, beat out my chest, I would shake, become disoriented and dizzy, and my chest would tighten up. My breathing would become very labored. This happened to me every night for over a week before I broke down and went to my PCP. He prescribed me wellbutrin 150 mg once a day for a week, to be increased to two a day if I don't see results. I also have bipolar disorder, which I'm not sure if my PCP knew.  Anyway, my side effects were NOT pleasant. For the first three days I was so restless I felt like I was going to claw my own skin off. I had TONS of energy. My nighttime panic attacks worsened. I felt like I was on coke. [LITERALLY]. I couldn't stop pacing, and my heart was racing. I couldn't sleep. I took my medication at 8pm as I'm generally a night owl, figuring this would be ample time for my body to adjust to the medication before sleep. I was up every day for 3 days until 6 am. Last night was the first day so far that I felt only mild symptoms. I was twitchy but able to sleep at my normal time [around 1 am]....It makes me somewhat apathetic. But once I would take the medicine during the first three or so days of treatment, let me tell you, it was HELL. I seriously considered stopping the medication because my anxiety was driving me crazy. I do have the jaw clenching still. If you can stick it out through the temporary hell, its not so bad for my mood. STAY CALM ON THIS MEDICINE- IT MAKES PANIC ATTACKS MUCH WORSE DURING THE FIRSTDAYS

column2: getakickoutofyou, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I started on 150mg of the generic Wellbutrin.  Within a day I had nausea, felt like throwing up, headaches, insomnia, and confusion.  Five days after starting, I woke up 5:30 am with such a severe headache I could hardly move, which was followed by severe nausea- my husband got a waste basket for me just in case because I could not move.  I had really bad chest pains added to this, and I counted the minutes till my doctors office opened at 8:00 am.  I had read that some people had more severe side effects with the generic version.  The active ingredient is the same amount in both, but the other components are different, causing some people to react differently.  I wanted to be prescribed Wellbutrin, not the generic, and within a day, most of the symptoms had gone.  What a relief.  It has been mostly a good change- I feel more calm, less anxious, and able to concentrate more, I feel almost "normal", but I still have some agitation and sometimes cry at small things, but do not feel depressed, if that makes any sense.  It usually only lasts a few minutes.  I think it would be beneficial to add another medication to this to maximize my results.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was recently diagnosed with depression and ADHD, so I was really hoping Wellbutrin would work.  I was prescribed 150mg, but after 5 days I had to get off.  I started to get increasingly shaky and I got a bad sore throat and dry mouth.  I didn't sleep for like 2 days, and I started to act kind of weird - like I blew everything out of proportion.  I also started to get nauseous and have headaches.  Anyway, the evening of the 5th day of being on Wellbutrin, I ended up having my first ever panic attack...the night before a final.  It was horrible - it was one of the worst nights of my life.  Thankfully I was able to get a hold of my psychiatrist who was able to get my final rescheduled - I know for a fact I would not have been in any shape to take it the next day.   Anyway, I'm disappointed Wellbutrin didn't work for me.  I realize that it helps a lot of people, but if you start to get these types of anxiety/mood symptoms, go off before it gets any worse - because it will, and it's not fun.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was put on Wellbutrin XL 150 for complaints of anxiousness associated with job related stress.  I was on Lexapro 5 mg which assisted me in not worrying about how I would manage to complete all the tasks of my demanding job each day.  However, the Lexapro gave me a zero sex drive.  At 30 years old, I was not comfortable with that. In the first week, I took 2.5 mg of Lexapro while starting Wellbutrin XL at the recommendation of my doctor.  The first week I did not have any problems, but by the second week, I began having racing feelings, hot flashes, chills, belly pain, and what seemed to be an increased heartbeat and off vision.  Additionally, I felt agitated and by week three, was crying off and on for no reason.  After four weeks of being on Wellbutrin XL (3 weeks of just Wellbutrin XL by itself since I was still taking Lexapro in the first week), I contacted my doctor, who as luck would have it, is on maternity leave now.  I attempted to taper every other day for a few days, but I felt worse on the day I took the drug versus the day I skipped.  I am now 12 days off Wellbutrin without tapering.  Nevertheless, I am still having hot flashes off and on and a racing heartbeat feeling.  It is not as bad as when I was taking the medication every day, but I still do not feel myself.  If you have just a bit of anxiety about how you can manage all that is required in a job which lots of responsibility and long hours, I would not recommend starting this drug.  I do not have depression,  yet most of what I am reading seems to indicate that people who need an extra push to get out of bed are the people that find this medicine useful.

column2: chris, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: I started taking Zoloft in 2005 to treat my anxiety/depression combo. I felt so much better on it but as of now, I am 40 lbs heavier. I have maintained the same weight for like past couple years prior to taking Zoloft and now I cannot stop gaining. It averages about 10 lbs a year and changes in diet and increases in exercise did nothing for me. I got frustrated and depressed about myself so I called my PCP and told him I wanted to try wellbutrin xl, because I heard its does the same thing and often causes people to lose weight rather than gain. I have been taking the generic Buproprion SR now for a little over a month and I am completely miserable. Apparently, people who have anxiety are not supposed to take this drug because it only treats depression and a side effect of it is an increase in anxiety. I have been experiencing loss of appetite but that come with nausea and queasiness-- I feel like I am pregnant (and I am not!). My head feels like its out of whack and I cant really describe the way that it messes with my vision and hearing without sounding like a whack job. My doctor should have known that this drug, with is an SNRI will not help me the way an SSRI does because of my anxiety. This past weekend I graduated college-- an important part of my life-- and I felt incredibly hostile and would go from screaming at my friends and family to bawling my eyes out in 2.5 secs. Thanks, doc. I am glad that I have google and WebMD to tell me what I should/should not take, because he apparently cannot.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have suffered with depression for approx 8 years. I have been prescribed Lexapro, Zoloft, Celexa and Paxil. Meds seem to work well for a time period (different with each medicine) & then they just seem to stop working for me.  I just recently switched from Paxil to Wellbutrin XL (generic). The first two days I took it, I felt wonderful! I felt like the old me again! Then I became dizzy & tired. I had constant headache & unending nausea - and I've only been taking it for about a week.  I haven't taken it in for two days now and I am still having horrible stomach problems and dizziness.  The only good thing so far is that I am not smoking as much, only about 2 or 3 cigarettes a day from smoking about a pack a day. Guess I will be going back to the doctor very soon for something else. I wish there was an easier way of finding a medication that worked. I feel like a lab rat going through all these different medicines! I wish everyone the best of luck with finding the medicine(s) that work for you.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I'm on my 4th day and can not wait to call me doctor when the office opens in 12 minutes!!  I'm on the generic XL, 150 and was told to go to 300 yesterday but I just could not do it.  I'm dizzy, withcy, impatient and full of energy (which is good) but not when I think everyone else is stupid and go on and on about it.  I can't drive safely to work so I took the day off. column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I've been on Wellbutrin xl 450mg/day for a little over two years now and for me it is what works. My mood doesn't flip at the slightest negative event and one annoying thing no longer ruins an entire day for me. I can think clearly and positively without losing my ability to be upset when there is a reason to be. (nothing like showing up to a funeral grinning and cracking jokes because you can't feel sad.) I don't have issues with getting up in the morning (well not ones that I didn't have long before the bipolar set in. I am not a morning person.) and I don't have the issues of manic episodes where I can't sleep until I have to be medicated into unconsciousness. I no longer constantly sit at my desk with the lights off holding a box cutter and staring at it for hours or go off on screaming rants about things that are trivial. I feel in control of myself and my actions as opposed to the constant feeling of being out of control; an observer in my own self destruction. This is what it does for me. Considering that we are all complex creatures of finely balanced chemicals it may not for you but that doesn't mean there isn't something that can help you regain control of your life. Take time with your physician to figure out what is right for you. And be picky it's your life if something isn't working go back to your doctor and try something else don't torture yourself and end up even worse.

column2: concerned patient from Birmingham, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have been on Wellbutrin XL for almost 5 years and in the last 3 years I have had to switch to the Bupropion XL. The wellbutrin itself worked great, I had loads of energy and did not experience any of the side effects. However, since I've switched to the buprpion,(due to insurance prefering everyone use Generic),I have tried 3 other antidepressants to try to help with the side effects. My mood has changed dramatically for the worse, no energy, headaches or migraines at least 3 times a week, have not even wanted to quit smoking, and now I am at the point of just staying alone, not want to join in family functions or talk to my closest friends. I highly recommend that anyone taking Bupropion XL talk to their physician about writing a letter of referal for the name brand Wellbutrin XL to the insurance company because the Generic is not the same and does not have the equality as the Wellbutrin.

column9: I have been on Wellbutrin for about 10 months.  In December I began taking the 300mg XL version.  It helped me tremendously.  I had so much energy and motivation to do things. If it's not working for you go to your doctor and try something else because these medicines can really change your entire personality.

column9: I give Wellbutrin 5 stars for ease of use, as it's just a regular pill.  However, I experienced a paradoxical reaction to the medicine about 48 hours after first use. I have had depression most of my life, and this beat everything I have ever felt (this was a -1 dose- effect, btw).  I quit taking it immediately and tossed it in the trash.  I had an appointment with my psychiatrist the next day, and told him all about it.  Normally, a doctor would say not to miss a dose (which I did by not taking it the next morning) without asking, but mine said he was glad I got off it.  Desipramine works better for me.Not suggesting that this is a poor drug; I'm sure it's great for many people.  However, believe it when they say it can have side effects or make you feel worse...

column2: czarina, ph.d., 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Generic WARNING. This is not about Wellbutrin, but the generic, Budeprion SR 150 mg x2. Irritability, jitters, at first, with 2nd dose at noon--super-witch, anger replaying itself. I've been retired about a year--I should be relaxed.

column2: Buberdean, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I am taking Wellbutrin SR. This stuff is so good they should put it in the water supply! I have energy, my spastic boss does not get me annoyed anymore. I am calm, I can deal with life's little problems much easier now. Have only been taking it for about a month. A little dry mouth is well worth it!! I have lost 16 pounds since I started taking it. No desire to drink any alcohol even a glass of wine tastes terrible now. Losing weight and feeling great!

column2: lazybonz,  Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have been on wellbutrin for 15 years-I came off of it for a short time but the anxiety caused me to return to it again. Like most depression sufferers I have tried many drugs over the years but this one has the least side effects and works great. I occasionally get dry mouth so you do need to stay hydrated.  I was a smoker and a drinker and have kicked both habits as the drug really does reduce cravings for any pleasure. Unfortunately that does include sex as well-it does decrease your libido but that can be overcome if you work at it! It does not decrease the pleasure level but the desire to get started just isn't there. I did have a period of time where I was not eating as it does also take away your cravings for food. My hubby loves to eat so he makes me eat too,so I have not had anorexia since I met him but I did with my first husband. So I would say that an understanding mate goes a long way toward helping to make this drug a success. I take 150 sr upon waking and before bed. My insurer is also pushing the generic but that did not work for me. I understand there are some generics that are better than others and if the cost is a factor you could try those first. I am convinced that wellbutin treats alcoholism because it runs in my family and I was a problem drinker until I took wellbutrin. I can have a drink now and not want another-but that may just be me. It is sure worth a try if you drink too much-I don't know why it is not more widely used for treating alcoholism because it works. You do have to take wellbutrin for 60 to 90 days to get the full effect of the drug.During that time you do have dry mouth but that subsides after a while and was not a significant problem for me. I am 62 years old so I don't know how much longer I will take it but the doctors seem to think that it is a lifelong drug. It has made a drastic change in my life and I recomend it highly!!

column2: sunshine , 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have had depression for many years and my doc put me on this drug quite a number of years ago.  It has helped me with mental capacities in thinking and not being so depressed as in the past.  If you need this drug I advise your pscychiatrist to consider this drug for you.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month
column9: I have been on antidepressants every since a bought with post partum 9 years ago.  I have tried it all.  Paxil made me sleepy and sweat but relieved anxiety, Prozac gave me tons of energy but made me 'crazy' and moody, Cymbalata made my anxiety go thru the roof, Celexa didn't do anything. I was on Zoloft for years, it was great for the anxiety but not the depression.  I slept a lot and just had no ambition to do anything more than I had to. I am now on the generic of this - 150 the first week and I am in day 2 of 300mg.  I LOVE IT SO FAR!!  My energy is through the roof, my fog of depression has lifted and I feel great.  My only side affect so far is that I seem to have an aching back, that could be due to the anxiety level needing to balance out.  However, I will take a slightly aching back over no energy and sleeping all of the time!One thing I have learned is that everyone reacts differently to each med. so you just have to find the one that works for you.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I began taking this drug when I was suffering from depression that was severe enough to affect my job, family relationships, socializing with friends, etc.  The difference between how I feel today versus one year ago has been profound. I combine Wellbutrin XL 150mg with Adderall XR 15mg during the week, and take just the Wellbutrin on weekends (when I don't work).  I have had few negative side effects-- the two noticeable are the dry mouth (the dryness affects intercourse as well) and hair loss, which I experienced when I was on the 300 mg dose.  I backed down to the 150mg and the hair loss has stopped.  I am grateful I was prescribed this drug first-- it really does work quite well.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
smytti36, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: -Generic Brand vs. Name Brand Wellbutrin XL-I've been on Wellbutrin for (about) a year and MUST comment on the effects of the generic brand, Bupropion (Sp?).    Because I don't have insurance, I spent a while on the generic version and failed to progress out of my depressive state. For a few weeks I felt like I was mildly feeling a change, but eventually it felt like I had plateaued, and shortly after, I returned to spiraling downward.    There were other medications added and subtracted to Wellbutrin in order to determine the right combination of drugs to aid my depression/anxiety/ADD. I AM POSITIVE that my only improvement was the result of other medications (Lamictal- mood stabilizer).    It has been documented that the generic version of this drug does NOT produce the same progressive results as the name brand. I can confidently say, that my experience w/ Bupropion was not a good one, in fact, I'd say it was horrible, and at times, worse than my initial state.   I have been back to taking the name brand Wellbutrin XL for about 3-4 months. I have continued to feel a drastic improvement in my mental state, and finally recognize the person that I knew I always was. It has enabled me to live my life again.      Although I have felt such a great improvement, the cost is $167 (that's with insurance), which is the CO-PAY! Without the insurance, the cost is $230-$270, and very few insurance companies offer reasonable coverage for Wellbutrin XL, since the generic version was approved.

column2: saynotoyeoh, 13-18 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Wellbutrin was a drug that worked terrificially for me. It definetly helped me overcome my depression for a while. However the drug did give me seizures. I'd take 5 or 6 Wellbutrins a day (as opposed to one)to get high and lose wieght. This gave me grand mal seizures. I stopped the drug and resumed my pill regimen months later, vowing to take only one pill a day. I did, but still had seizures. The seizures weren't a result of overdosing on the wellbutrin. They happened because I was taking them while abusing street drugs (Ecstasy and Cocaine). Please, tell you doctor if you have a drug problem or are prone to overdosing on OTC/prescription pills for fun. I crashed my car into a tree during one of the seizures I had. (PS Do not take if you have an eating disorder. Weight loss is common in users)

column2: me27513, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: Why do docs use only one drug at a time? After 20 years of experimenting with SSRIs, I have an almost ideal combo of Wellbutrin XL (generic) 150 mg each morning PLUS Lexapro 10 mg each night. Wellbutrin made me hyper at first, so I lowered the dosage. It has no negative sexual side effects, so it balances Lexapro nicely (in fact, it has the opposite effect). No weight gain, late-night munchies, sleeping all the time. It's truly different from all the rest. Effexor was awful, Paxil made me fat, Zoloft made me sleepy, Prozac made me nuts, and none of those helped my depression. Wellbutrin saved me, I don't build up a tolerance (even after 10 years), and its generics are so much cheaper than the alternatives. If you're not doing well with the standard Rx, try this...it's truly different, and ask your doc about combining meds.

column9: I had to vote along the middle on this one. It took about 3 months for it to fully work. For 8 months I felt absolutely wonderful. I had energy & drive to exercise, I smiled & laughed again. Did not help my anxiety but I still take Lorazepam for that. In the last 3 weeks (about a year since I started it) I've become very depressed, irritated at stupid things, angry. This morning my doctor said sometimes it just doesn't work anymore. She prescribed Cymbalta so I'm going to wean off of Wellbutrin while weaning onto Cymbalta over the next 6 weeks.  I do know people who got WORSE using Wellbutrin, I know some who love it after years of use. I was right in the middle. I loved it but it just stopped working. Also I lost the 25 lbs that I had gained on Lexapro once the Wellbutrin worked.

column2: Confused in PHX, 55-64 Female  (Patient)
column9: Into my 3rd week on the generic Wellbutrin XL/300mg., 1 x per day in the A.M.  First week thought it was a miracle drug, my gloomy mood gone/energy level soared! Great appetite suppressant!!
